definition: [chK or [chk is the eleventh letter of the English alphabet
for [chkilometres.

example: The next town is about 40 k from here

definition: A [chkaleidoscope is a toy which consists of a tube containing pieces of coloured glass and mirrors
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective kaleidoscopic' The folk dancers' bright costumes created a kaleidoscopic scene.
example: When you look through it, you see colourful symmetrical patterns which change as you turn it

definition: The [chkangaroo is a native animal of Australia
example: It has powerful hind legs and a tail for leaping, and a small head and short front legs.  The female carries her young in a pouch

definition: [chKarate is a Japanese style of self-defence which involves fighting without weapons
example: You use only your hands, feet, elbows and knees

definition: A [chkayak is a light, covered canoe used in sport
[chKebab is the shortened form of [chshish kebab
example: A kebab consists of small pieces of grilled meat on a thin stick or skewer

definition: [ch1' The [chkeel of a boat is the long piece of timber or metal that stretches along the bottom and supports the rest of the frame.  [ch2' [chkeel over'  '
example: If someone or something [chkeels over, they fall over suddenly.  They collapse.  [cf2]Khaled was so weak after his illness, he nearly keeled over as he tried to get out of bed

definition: [ch1' Someone who is [chkeen is eager and enthusiastic to do something.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb keenly' [j35]'noun keenness'
example: I'm keen to try the new restaurant that has just opened. [j33] Peter is a keen stamp collector[j4]he spends many hours on his hobby.  [ch2' '[cf2]adjective If your senses or feelings are [chkeen, they are clear and strong.  [cf2]Dogs have a keen sense of smell. [j33] ...a keen desire.  [ch3' '[cf2]adjective An edge that is [chkeen is sharp.  [cf2]Be careful how you use that new knife[j4]it has a very keen blade.  [ch4' [chkeen on'  '[cf2] If you are [chkeen on someone or something, you are interested in or fond of them.  [cf2]I'm not at all keen on jazz music. [j33] Anjali is very keen on her new boyfriend

definition: [ch1' If someone or something [chkeeps in a particular state or place, they remain in that state or place.
note: ... THE OPPOSITE of sense 15 is [chgive up.
example: I wish they would keep quiet. [j33] KEEP LEFT [j33] Are you keeping well? [j33] The drinks kept cool for quite some time.  [ch2a' '[cf2]verb If someone or something [chkeeps an action going, they continue to do it.  [cf2]She wanted to keep working in the office till the end of the month. [j33] They kept him guessing for a long while. [j33] The population keeps increasing.  [chb ' '[cf2]verb If someone or something [chkeeps doing something, they do it over and over again.  [cf2]The wind kept blowing over the pot plants on the veranda. [j33] I keep forgetting to post that letter.  [ch3' '[cf2]verb If you [chkeep something, you retain it.  You don't give it away. [cf2]Our cat had kittens[j4]we kept one and gave the rest away. [j33] That's a good photo[j4]can I keep it? [ch4 ' '[cf2]verb If you [chkeep someone from doing something, or something from happening, you prevent them doing it or prevent it from happening.  [cf2]We must fix the fence to keep the dog from getting out. [j33] Our boss tried to keep the scandal from reaching the headlines. [j33] The blinds kept the sun from shining into the room.  [ch5' '[cf2]verb If you [chkeep a promise or appointment, you carry out what you said you would, or you do what was arranged.  [cf2]I mustn't forget to keep my dental appointment.  [ch6' '[cf2]verb If you own animals and look after them, you [chkeep them.  [cf2]Vinotha kept a dog all her life. [j33] They keep chickens and ducks on their farm.  [ch7' '[cf2]verb If you [chkeep a record of something, you write it down. [cf2]Karen kept a diary of her trip. [j33] He keeps a list of his expenses. [j33] ...keep an account.  [ch8' '[cf2]verb If food [chkeeps, it remains good.  [cf2]I can't drink all this milk[j4] will it keep till tomorrow?  [ch9' '[cf2]verb [chKeep has meanings like 'remain' or 'retain' when it is followed by adverbs such as 'away', 'off' and 'out'.  [cf2]Medicine should be kept away from children. [j33] Keep off the grass. [j33] PRIVATE PROPERTY[j4]KEEP OUT!  [ch10' '[cf2]noun Your [chkeep is the cost of your needs of living, such as food, clothing and shelter.  [cf2]Sanjay's parents made him work for his keep.  [ch11' [chkeep at'  '[cf2] If you [chkeep at something, you continue working at what you have started.  You persist with it.  [cf2]I'm sick of this ironing but I'll keep at it till it's finished.  [ch12' [chkeep back'  '[cf2] If you [chkeep back information or knowledge, you don't tell it.  [cf2]The witness was uneasy and appeared to be keeping back important facts. [ch[ch13 ' [chkeep down'  '[cf2] If you [chkeep down the size of something, you stop it from increasing.  You do not let it get bigger.  [cf2]The company made a good profit by keeping down costs. [j33] Quang keeps his weight down by eating sensibly.  [ch14' [chkeep to'  '[cf2] If you [chkeep to something, you carry out what you agreed to do or what is expected of you.  [cf2]Let's keep to our original plan and leave early. [j33] Contestants who don't keep to the rules will be disqualified.  [ch15' [chkeep up (a)'  '[cf2] If someone or something [chkeeps up with another, they continue at the same speed or rate. [cf2]I can't keep up with your fast pace. [j33] Wages are sure to rise to keep up with inflation.  [ch(b)' [ch'  '[cf2] If you [chkeep up something, you continue to do it.    [cf2]You're making excellent progress[j4]keep up the good work. [j33] Amal works long hours to keep up both jobs

definition: A [chkeeper is someone who guards or looks after things or animals.
example: The keeper has to be careful about changing the diet of the monkeys[j4]some foods seem to make them cranky. [j33] ...goalkeeper. [j33] ...wicket-keeper. [j33] ...housekeeper

definition: [ch1' If something is in your [chkeeping, it is in your care.
example: I hope the money is safe in your keeping.  [ch2' [chin keeping with'  '[cf2] If some~ thing is [chin keeping with something else, it is suitable for it or in harmony with it.  [cf2]Her modern ideas were in keeping with the times

definition: A [chkeepsake is something that you keep in memory of a person or event.  It is like a memento.
example: The ring was a keepsake from her grandmother

[chKelp is a type of large brown seaweed
A [chkennel is a house built for a dog to sleep in
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb kennel (kennels, kennelled, kennelling)' They kennelled their dog when they went on holidays.

definition: [chKero is the shortened form of [chkerosene

definition: [chKetchup is a spicy cold sauce usually made from tomatoes and eaten with meat or sausages
note: ... NOTE This is an American word.  [chTomato sauce is the common expression for it in Australian English.

definition: A [chkettle is a container for boiling water.  It has a handle, a lid, and a spout for easy pouring.
example: I'll put the kettle on so we can make a cup of tea

definition: [ch1a' A [chkey is a small piece of specially shaped metal.  It is used to open a lock.
example: I wish I hadn't locked my suitcase[j4]I can't find the key to open it.  [chb' '[cf2]noun A [chkey is also used to start a car engine or machinery, and to wind up clocks or toys.  [cf2]Which is the ignition key to the car?  [ch2' '[cf2]noun The [chkey is something that explains how to understand things such as maps, diagrams or codes. [cf2]Look in the front of the book for the key to the abbreviations. [j33] Where's the key that gives the scale of this map? [j33] ...key to the mystery.  [ch3a' '[cf2]noun A [chkey is one of the black and white movable parts on a piano or organ that you press with your fingers to make music.  [chb' '[cf2]noun A [chkey is one of the set of parts that you press to use a typewriter or computer.  [ch4' '[cf2]noun In music, a [chkey is the name given to a series of notes that are related to each other and form the major or minor scales.  [cf2]This piece is written in the key of E minor.  [ch5' '[cf2]adjective The [chkey part or person in something is the most important one.  [cf2]The key witness for the prosecution will give evidence tomorrow. [j33] The key issues of the election campaign are not very clear. [j33] ...key industries. [ch6 ' [chkey in '  '[cf2] If you [chkey in data or instructions into a computer, you enter them by using the keyboard. [cf2]I had to work back and key in the sales statistics for last month.  [ch7' [chkeyed up'  '[cf2] If you are [chkeyed up, you are excited or nervous about something.  [cf2]Leif was very keyed up before his interview

definition: A [chkeyboard is the set of keys on a typewriter, computer or piano
[ch1' In music, the [chkeynote is the first note of a key or scale.  [ch2' '

definition: for [chkilogram or [chkilograms.

definition: [chKhaki is a greenish- brown colour
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective khaki' The soldiers were wearing their khaki uniforms.

definition: If wheat or grain has been [chkibbled, it has been ground into small particles
[ch1' When a person or animal [chkicks, they strike with their foot.
example: The boys were kicking a ball around the oval. [j33] The horse kicked him in the shins. [j33] You must kick hard with your legs to be a good swimmer.  [ch2' '[cf2]noun A [chkick is a hit or blow with the foot.  [cf2]Sometimes my lawnmower just seems to need a good kick to get it started.  [ch3' '[cf2]noun In informal language, when you talk about a [chkick, you mean something which gives you a thrill, or pleases you greatly.  [cf2]She gets a kick out of playing poker machines. [j33] Let's go for a midnight swim just for a bit of a kick.  [ch4' [chkick out'  '[cf2] In informal language, if you say you [chkicked someone [chout of a job or place, you mean you got rid of them.  [cf2]They kicked him out of the club for swearing. [j33] She was kicked out of school for stealing.  [ch5' [chkick the bucket'  '[cf2] In informal language, if you say that someone has [chkicked the bucket, you mean they have died.  [ch6' [chkick the habit'  '[cf2] In informal language, if you say you have [chkicked the habit, you mean that you have given up an addiction.  [cf2]Nino doesn't smoke any more[j4]he's kicked the habit.  [ch7' [chkick up'  '[cf2] In informal language, if you say you [chkicked up a fuss or row, you mean that you caused trouble by complaining loudly about something that has upset you.  [cf2]The service in the restaurant was so slow that people started to kick up a fuss. [j33] I know he will kick up a row when he finds out about the ding in his car.  [ch8' [chkick yourself'  '[cf2] If you say you could [chkick yourself, you mean that you are annoyed with yourself for doing something wrong or stupid.  [cf2]I could have kicked myself for not checking the time of that TV program[j4]now I've missed seeing it

definition: [ch1' In informal language, you can call a child or young person a [chkid.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective kid' He has a kid sister and an older brother.
example: Our neighbours have three teenage kids.  [ch2' '[cf2]noun A [chkid is a young goat.  [ch3' '[cf2]verb In informal language, if you [chkid someone, you say things that are not true, as a joke, to trick them.  [cf2]Don't take him seriously[j4]he's only kidding. [j33] Eva tried to kid them into believing that she had hurt herself

definition: If someone is [chkidnapped, they are taken away by force and held prisoner.  Often money is demanded for their release.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun kidnapper'
example: Police are looking for the man who kidnapped the small child

definition: Your [chkidneys are the two organs in your lower back area which remove liquid waste from the blood by producing urine
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective See [chrenal'.

definition: [ch1' When someone or something [chkills a person, animal or plant, they cause them to die.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun kill' After much stalking, the lion made a kill.[j35]'noun killer'
example: Spiders kill insects for food. [j33] Fifty people were killed in the plane crash. [j33] Garden pests have killed these plants.  [ch2' '[cf2]verb If you [chkill something, you destroy it or end it.  [cf2]He made the wrong decision and killed his chances of promotion. [j33] Cold weather is killing our hope of finding the man alive.  [ch3' '[cf2]verb If you [chkill time, you occupy yourself with something to make time pass while you are waiting for something else.  [cf2]I always keep a paperback or magazine handy to kill time at airports

definition: A [chkilling is a murder.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective killing'

example: She's on a diet trying to lose two kilos

example: The symbol for this is [chK

definition: A [chkilohertz is a unit of frequency equal to 1000 cycles per second
example: The abbreviation for this is [chkHz

Your [chkin are the members of your family and your relatives
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective kin'

definition: [ch1' Someone who is [chkind is caring and thoughtful.
note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is [chunkind.   [ch2' 'noun A group of things or people that have similar qualities or are of the same type are a [chkind. What kind of fruit do you like?  The street was littered with all kinds of rubbish.  This isn't a good brand[j4]do you have another kind?  [ch3' [cha kind of or [chkind of'  ' Phrases like [cha kind of or [chkind of are used when you are not certain how to describe something or when you are only certain to an extent.  I have a kind of idea that might work.  She was kind of disappointed.   ... NOTE A polite way of asking someone to do something for you is to use an expression like 'Would you be kind enough to... and 'Would you be so kind as to....  [j32] ... WORD FAMILY 'noun kindness'
example: She was the kindest lady I have ever known. [j33] It was kind of you to water our garden while we were away

definition: [ch1' If something [chkindles or you kindle something, it starts to burn or you set it alight.

definition: [chKindling is material, such as dry sticks or leaves, that you use to start a fire.
example: Let's gather some kindling and burn those big logs

definition: [ch1' A [chkindly person is someone who is sympathetic and tries to help.
note: ... NOTE You can use [chkindly to tell someone in a firm way to stop doing something that annoys you, as in 'Kindly refrain from smoking. or 'Will you kindly listen to me?
example: She could always go to her kindly aunt for advice.  [ch2' '[cf2]adverb If you do something [chkindly, you do it in a kind manner.  [cf2]He acted kindly towards the strangers. [j33] ...to speak kindly

definition: [chThings that are [chkindred are related by a common source or have similar qualities
is the shortened form of kindergarten'
[ch1' A [chking is a man who rules over a country or empire.  He is descended from a royal family.

[cf2]He was the cattle king of the district. [j33] ...Tarzan, king of the apes.  [ch3' '[cf2]noun In the game of chess, the [chking is the main playing piece.  [ch4' '[cf2]noun A [chking is any of the four playing cards with a picture of a king on it.  [ch5' '[cf2]adjective Something that is [chking size is very large.  [cf2]They bought a king size bed. [j33] How much are king prawns today? [j33] ...a king tide

example: It is hard to comb your hair[j4]it is full of kinks. [j33] ...a kink in the garden hose.  [ch2' '[cf2]noun A [chkink is also something unusual about someone's sexual behaviour

example: When you ski you have to bend your knees a lot. [j33] Martha was bouncing the baby on her knee.  [ch2' '[cf2]noun The [chknee is the part of a pair of trousers that covers the knee. [ch3' [chbring to your knees'  '[cf2] If you say someone or something is [chbrought to their knees, you mean that they are forced to accept defeat.  [cf2]The prolonged recession brought the industry to its knees

definition: Your [chkneecap is the flat bone at the front of your knee
If you [chkneel, you rest on one or both knees.
example: The congregation was kneeling in prayer. [j33] Emine knelt down by the stream to get a drink of water

definition: [ch1' A [chknife is a tool for cutting things, or it can be a weapon. It has a handle and a sharp blade.
example: We need to set an extra knife and fork on the table for Annie. [j33] Don't cut your fingers on the sharp kitchen knife. [ch2 ' '[cf2]verb If you [chknife someone, you wound them with a knife.  [cf2]The attacker crept up and knifed him in the leg

definition: [ch1' In the Middle Ages, a [chknight was a man with a high position in society who fought in wars for the king.  [ch2' '

definition: [ch1' When you [chknit, you make a garment or fabric from strands of wool or yarn using long needles or a machine.

example: I like to knit while watching TV. [j33] She knitted the baby some mittens.  [ch2' '[cf2]verb If someone or something [chknits, they join or become closely joined.  [cf2]The plaster cast must stay on your leg till the bones knit. [j33] The tragedy had knitted the family more closely together

definition: [chKnitting is the article that you knit or the act of knitting.

definition: [ir(s76),(s75+6)]knob   [ch1' A [chknob is a round handle for opening things or for turning things on or off.
example: The new house featured brass knobs on cup~ boards and doors. [j33] Don't let Sally play with the knobs on the radio.  [ch2' '[cf2]noun A [chknob is a round lump.  [cf2]The old tree was covered with knobs. [j33] The curtain rod had gold knobs at each end. [j33] ...a knob of butter

definition: [oi0,(s75+6)]   [ch1' If someone or something [chknocks on a door or window, they tap or strike it.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun knock' [j35]'noun knockout'
example: You must knock before you enter. [j33] A branch was knocking on the window in the storm.  [ch2' '[cf2]verb If you [hmp1][chknock something, you bump it.  [cf2]She accidentally knocked the vase and spilt the water. [j33] In the crush she was knocked against the wall.  [ch3' '[cf2]verb In informal language, if you say you [chknock someone or something, you mean you criticise or find fault with them.  [cf2]Why do you always knock my ideas? [j33] She was unfairly knocking him about his golf.  [ch4' [chknock about (a)'  '[cf2] If you [chknock someone or something [chabout, you handle them roughly.  [cf2]He always knocks the dog about when he gets angry. [j33] You need a new schoolbag[j4]you've knocked the old one about dreadfully.  [ch(b)' [ch'  '[cf2] If you [chknock about, you wander from place to place and don't[xthead,knot[xx stay or live anywhere very long.  [cf2]He knocked about all over Australia for two years before he settled down in Queensland.  [ch5' [chknock around with' '[cf2] In informal language, if you say you [chknock around with someone, you spend time with them as a friend.  [cf2]She knocks around with a group her own age.  [ch6' [chknock back (a)'  '[cf2] If you [chknock back some~ thing, you refuse it.  [cf2]He knocked back an invitation to the cricket match.  [ch(b)' [ch'  '[cf2] If something [chknocks you [chback, it puts you in a worse position than you were in before.  [cf2]The holiday will knock us back a few hundred dollars.  [ch7' [chknock down (a)'  '[cf2] If you [chknock down someone or something, you strike them down to the ground.  [cf2]She was knocked down in the street by a car. [j33] They knocked down the old fence and built a new one.  [ch(b)' [ch'  '[cf2] If you [chknock down the price of something, you reduce it.  [ch(c)' [ch'  '[cf2] In an auction, when a lot is [chknocked down, it is sold to the highest bidder.  [cf2]Lot 305 was knocked down to Mrs Jones for $95.  [ch8' [chknock it off'  '[cf2] In informal language, you say [chknock it off when you want to stop something such as an argument or fight.  It means 'stop it!'  [ch9' [chknock off (a)'  '[cf2] When you [chknock off, you stop an activity that you have been doing. [cf2]He usually knocks off work at 6 o'clock. [j33] When do you knock off?  [ch(b)' [ch'  '[cf2] In informal language, if you say someone [chknocks off something, you mean they steal or rob it.  [cf2]Shop detectives watch out for people knocking off goods. [j33] There was another attempt to knock off the bank.  [ch10' [chknock on the head'  '[cf2] When you [chknock an idea or plan [chon the head, you put a stop to it.  [cf2]That silly scheme of his will have to be knocked on the head before it goes any further.  [ch11' [chknock out (a)'  '[cf2] When boxers [chknock out their opponent, they knock them down and defeat them.  [ch(b) ' [ch'  '[cf2] If someone [chknocks you [chout, they make you unconscious by hitting you.  A drug can also knock you out.  [ch(c)' [ch'  '[cf2] If you [chknock yourself [chout, you tire yourself with too much hard work. [cf2]I knocked myself out trying to get the job finished before the deadline.  [ch(d) ' [ch'  '[cf2] If something [chknocks you [chout, it stuns you greatly.  It impresses you very much.  [cf2]We were knocked out by the grandeur of the occasion.  [ch12' [chknock together'  '[cf2] If you [chknock together something, you make it quickly and roughly.  [cf2]He knocked together a swing and a seesaw for the kids.  [ch13' [chknock up (a)'  '[cf2] If you [chknock up someone, you wake them by knocking on their door.  [ch(b)' [ch'  '[cf2] If you [chknock up something, you arrange or make it in a hurry.  [cf2]How about staying for lunch?[j4]I'll knock up some sandwiches

definition: [ir(s76),(s75+6)]knot   [ch1' A [chknot is the part where pieces of thread, string or rope are tied together.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb knot (knots, knotted, knot~ ting)' She's knotted this so tightly I haven't got a hope of undoing it.
example: Pull the knot tight so it won't come undone. [j33] It's hard to get the knots out of this string.  [ch2' '[cf2]noun A [chknot[ch in wood is where a branch has joined a tree and left a fault in the grain.  [ch3' '[cf2]noun A [chknot is a unit of speed, about equal to 1.85 kmh.  The speed of ships, aircraft and wind is measured in knots.  [cf2]The boat was travelling at 25 knots

definition: [ch1' If you [chknow something, you understand it to be true or a fact.  You are certain in your mind about it.
example: He knew they were away on holidays last month. [j33] I know you have a new job[j4]I've known it for a week.  [ch2' '[cf2]verb If you [chknow something, you have learnt it and can do it.  [cf2]I know how to cook.   [ch3' '[cf2]verb If you [chknow a person or a place, you are familiar with them.  [cf2]He knew the city well ten years ago, but it has changed. [j33] They won't leave early[j4]I know them, they'll stay till the very end.  [ch4' [chI know'  '[cf2] People often use [chI know to show that they suddenly have an idea. [cf2]What can we do in the holidays that's different?[j4] I know, let's go mining for opals at Lightning Ridge. [ch5 ' [chin the know'  '[cf2] If you are [chin the know about something, you have inside information which other people do not have.  [cf2]He's in the know or he wouldn't have sold those shares when he did.  [ch6' [chknow backwards'  '[cf2] You say you [chknow something [chbackwards if you know it or understand it very well.  [cf2]She had recited the poem so many times that she knew it backwards. [j33] He could never get lost in this place[j4]he knows it backwards.  [ch7' [chlet someone know'  '[cf2] If you [chlet someone know about something, you tell them about it.  [cf2]Let me know when you need the book back. [j33] If we're running late, we'll let you know.  [ch8' [chyou know'  '[cf2] [chYou know is often used in conversation to keep it flowing or to keep the listener interested.  It doesn't always have much meaning.  [cf2]They're really nice people, you know, but they're always short of money. [j33] You know, I've been wondering what to do..

definition: [ch1' A [chknowing look or remark is one that shows that you have a secret understanding of something, more than is obvious.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb knowingly' It wasn't an accident[j4]he did it knowingly.
example: He turned his head and gave us a knowing wink. [ch2 ' '[cf2]adjective Someone who is [chknowing is intelligent and wise

definition: [ch1a' Your [chknowledge is the experience and facts you have gained or learnt through living and studying.  It is what you know.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective knowledgeable'
example: He has a vast knowledge of marine animals. [j33] She doesn't seem to have much knowledge about bringing up children.  [chb' '[cf2]noun [chKnowledge is the awareness of a fact or happening.  [cf2]She had no knowledge of his disappearance.  [ch2' [chto the best of your knowledge'  '[cf2] If you say that something is the case [chto the best of your knowledge, you mean that you think it is true but you are not completely sure.  [cf2]The outdoor concert will take place, to the best of my knowledge, regardless of the weather

definition: [chKnown is the past participle of [chknow.  [fp[gc--knuckle 'times,0'[cp8.5][j24]n... k[j17]l'  [ch1' '
note: ... SEE THE PICTURE at [chbody.   [ch2' [chknuckle down'  ' If you [chknuckle down to a task, you work hard at it.  It's about time she knuckled down and completed her diploma.
example: noun Your [chknuckles are your finger joints

definition: A [chkoala is a furry, grey, Australian animal that lives and feeds in certain types of gum tree
A [chkookaburra is an Australian bird with a harsh call which sounds like laughter
note: ... OTHER NAMES for this bird are [chlaughing kook~ aburra and [chlaughing jackass.
example: It eats mainly fish

definition: [chKosher is used to describe food, especially meat, that has been prepared according to Jewish law.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb kosher'
example: Is this food kosher? [j33] ...a kosher restaurant
